questions.hint: In the absence of an oral or written advance directive for a deceased individual, a surrogate decision-maker (SDM) should be designated to act in their best interest. An SDM may be designated by a patient prior to loss of capacity (e.g., durable medical power of attorney), legally appointed (a court-appointed guardian), or appointed via default sequence among the next of kin.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of lower back pain. The pain wakes him up at night and radiates down to his legs. During this time, he has also had stiffness of his back muscles. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles bilaterally. The physician decides to prescribe acetaminophen. During a follow-up examination, the patient reports feeling somewhat better but says he is “a bit tired and sleepy throughout the day.” The physician reviews the patient's prescription and notices that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Disclose the error to the patient
Switch medication to acetaminophen
Continue with the current drug regimen
Prescribe a topical analgesic ointment
Refer the patient to physical rehabilitation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A medication error occurs when the patient receives the wrong drug or the correct drug at an incorrect dose, frequency, and/or via an incorrect route. Physicians should disclose medical errors to patients regardless of the outcome of the error, so disclosure should be the first step even though this patient feels better and only has some drowsiness. Disclosure of medical errors involves clearly stating that an error has occurred, describing the nature of the error, and expressing personal regret or apology. Timely, full disclosure of errors is beneficial for the physician-patient relationship and patient safety.

Medication errors can occur at any of the stages of drug prescription (ordering, transcribing, dispensing, administering). The physician should also report this error via an incident reporting system. If the cause of an error is not immediately known, the physician should inform the patient and maintain contact while investigations carried out. A root-cause analysis should be performed, and appropriate strategies should be implemented to prevent the medication error from recurring (e.g., medication reconciliation at transitions of care, the use of a computerized provider order entry).

B) INCORRECT:

The physician can prescribe acetaminophen for the treatment of this patient's acute lumbosacral radiculopathy, as originally intended. Unlike cyclobenzaprine, acetaminophen does not commonly cause drowsiness and would, therefore, be an appropriate choice for this patient. However, this action does not directly address the fact that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Another step is required first.

C) INCORRECT:

The physician likely should not continue the current drug regimen. Although cyclobenzaprine can be used to treat acute lumbosacral radiculopathy, cyclobenzaprine is generally avoided in elderly patients because of the risk of sedation, which this patient is experiencing. Before prescribing any drug, the patient should be informed of the risks and benefits in order to make fully informed decisions.

D) INCORRECT:

The physician can prescribe a topical analgesic ointment, which may be part of a stepwise approach in conservative treatment of lumbosacral pain. However, this action does not directly address the fact that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Another step is required first.

E) INCORRECT:

The physician can refer the patient to physical rehabilitation, which may be helpful for managing his acute lumbosacral radiculopathy. However, referring the patient to a different specialist does not directly address the fact that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Another step is required first.
questions.hint: This elderly patient with acute lumbosacral radiculopathy was inadvertently prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a muscle relaxant, instead of a nonopioid analgesic (medication error).

questions.text: A 31-year-old homeless and uninsured man is brought to the emergency department because he was found agitated and yelling for help. He is well known to the emergency department and has been in and out of the hospital 6 times in the past month for various issues. He has used up his allotted health care assistance program limit and has an outstanding debt to the hospital. When the physician speaks to him, the man states that he just used some drugs that his friend gave him and now has chest pain. Except for illicit drug use, his past medical history is unknown. He appears unkempt. He is diaphoretic and malodorous but oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?

choices.text: "We will need to set up health insurance coverage for you with the county healthcare assistance program before treating you."
"We will treat you to the best of our ability, but we will not be liable in the event of medical negligence."
"We will check your vital signs and do a workup of your chest pain, but we will have to deny further treatment if the cause of your chest pain is not a medical emergency."
"We will help you get transferred to the nearest hospital, but we cannot treat you since you have used up your allotted health care assistance program limit at our hospital."
"We will treat you only if you commit to enrolling in a drug rehabilitation program."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's health insurance coverage. Once the patient is stabilized, it would be appropriate to assist him in finding additional healthcare coverage (e.g., through a county healthcare assistance program for low-income patients).

B) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS). The hospital and/or treating physician may still be held liable in the event of medical negligence.

C) CORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is obligated to screen for emergency medical conditions if requested and, if such a condition exists, provide treatment until that condition is stabilized. Failure to diagnose and treat ACS would endanger this patient's life. The EMTALA defines an emergency medical condition as a medical condition that manifests with acute symptoms (including pain and labor contractions) that are sufficiently severe to (i) place the health of the individual or unborn child in serious jeopardy, (ii) seriously impair bodily functions, or (iii) cause serious dysfunction of an organ or body part.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's financial limitations. Transferring the patient to another hospital is appropriate if the hospital is not equipped or staffed to properly evaluate and treat a patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's willingness to participate in a drug rehabilitation program. Once the patient is stabilized, it is appropriate to assist him in enrolling in such a program.
questions.hint: This patient with chest pain and diaphoresis might have acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which is a potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request?

choices.text: Consult the institutional review board overseeing the trial
Unblind the participant by revealing which group she was in
Destroy all clinical and diagnostic data collected on the participant so far
Ask the participant if she is willing to undergo any follow-up evaluation
Offer remaining compensation for subsequent visits

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All clinical trials are required to have institutional review board (IRB) approval before enrolling participants and conducting research. The IRB should be notified in the event of a protocol deviation (e.g., including a participant who does not meet the required criteria, dosing error) or adverse event. Although study withdrawal should be documented, participants are allowed to withdraw from studies without prior consultation with the IRB.

B) INCORRECT:

The protocol for unblinding is determined by the institutional review board at the beginning of a trial. Specific circumstances, such as a subject's pregnancy or adverse events that affect safety, may require unblinding participants. Investigators may also decide to unblind participants after completion of the trial. However, withdrawal from a study is not an obligatory reason to unblind the participant and another action is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Study participants may withdraw at any time, and all data gathered about them should be secured. To ensure patient confidentiality, it may be further necessary to anonymize the data. However, the FDA and OHRP guidelines for clinical drug trials stipulate that all data collected prior to withdrawal must remain in the study database to ensure validity of the research and enable intention-to-treat analysis if needed.

D) CORRECT:

A participant has a right to withdraw from a clinical trial at any time. The investigator should accept the decision without attempting to influence the participant in any way but may inquire about the reason for withdrawal to identify any potential risks or adverse events. In addition, the investigator should clarify whether the participant wants to withdraw completely (i.e., from all aspects of the study including follow-up) or only partially. Follow-up is important for ensuring the validity of the research and identifying adverse events that could negatively affect other participants. Informed consent on partial participation should be obtained. In the event of complete withdrawal, the participant should not be contacted for further study-related activities, and no additional information should be collected about them. The information collected to date may be kept.

E) INCORRECT:

The type of compensation is determined prior to study enrollment and should be uniformly applicable to all participants. Prorated compensation is used for studies involving multiple visits. This compensation model equitably distributes compensation among participants and pays participants a predetermined amount for each procedure and/or visit. With this compensation model, a participant who wishes to withdraw completely from the study should not be denied compensation that they have already earned but should not be offered compensation for the subsequent visits because such an action may go against the principle of justice for the other participants and risks imposing an element of undue influence on the withdrawing participant to remain (either completely or partially) in the study. Another action is necessary before discussing compensation.

Regardless of the type of compensation model used, a study participant may be eligible for additional compensation if they experienced adverse events from the intervention.
questions.hint: This patient wants to discontinue her participation in a human subjects research study. The investigator should follow the guidelines set forth by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a routine health examination. According to the patient's mother, the boy has been more withdrawn lately and has also lost some weight, which she finds “suspicious.” Their family moved from a different state 6 months ago. The boy has some difficulty making friends at the new school but has good academic performance. He enjoys playing drums and has a good appetite. The patient says he tried beer before but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are normal. Physical and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. The physician reassures the parents that their son is experiencing a normal stress reaction. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother asks if she could talk to the physician in private. When left alone with the physician, the mother says: “I think my son is lying about the drug use. Could you please run a drug test on him but tell him it is just a routine laboratory test?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "We can perform this test only if you as a parent sign a liability waiver."
"I understand your concern and will schedule the test for our next appointment."
"I do not think your son is using drugs, since his examination showed no abnormalities."
"I cannot lie to your son about the nature of the test. Why do you think your son is lying about the drug use?"
"I could do this, but I think it would be better if you discussed your concerns with your son first."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no liability waiver applicable for the scenario presented in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Empathetic communication with a patient and/or their family promotes a trusting relationship, which can ultimately improve the care of the patient. However, physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth, and deceiving the patient would be inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

This response is prematurely dismissive of the parent's concerns and does not allow for investigation of the underlying reason for her concerns. Moreover, a normal physical and mental examination cannot rule out substance use disorders.

D) CORRECT:

Physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth. Lying to a patient will likely damage the physician-patient relationship and possibly impede future care. Moreover, parental consent for medical care of an unemancipated minor is not required in matters of sex (e.g., contraception, pregnancy care except for abortion in most states, STIs) or addiction care; in these instances, minors can receive care without their parent's knowledge or consent. This patient's physical and mental examinations provide no evidence of compromised decision-making capacity, indicating that he is able to provide informed consent for his own medical care. In the case presented here, the physician should acknowledge the mother's concerns, investigate the underlying reasons for her request by asking open-ended questions, and explain the limitations of drug testing (e.g., false positives, false negatives). If the physician concludes that a drug screening test is appropriate, the next step would be to meet privately with the patient and seek his consent. Minors should also be encouraged to discuss their issues with their parents.

E) INCORRECT:

Encouraging parents to openly discuss their concerns with their children (and vice versa) is always recommended. However, physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth, and deceiving the patient would be inappropriate.
questions.hint: Regardless of the medical issue, it is preferable for the physician to gain the minor's approval before starting medical care.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but they can still legally request records about your diagnosis."
"I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents only if you are legally emancipated."
"I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but I am obligated to inform your partner of your diagnosis."
"I can prescribe you antibiotics only if one of your parents consents."
"I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, and I recommend that your partner get tested."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's information is confidential and should not be shared with his parents unless he gives consent. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

B) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; legal emancipation is not required.

C) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; parental consent is not required. Furthermore, all individuals who have had sexual contact with patients diagnosed with Neisseria gonorrhea in the 60 days preceding the diagnosis should be evaluated and treated. However, these individuals should be notified via a public health official or by the index patient, not by the physician. In most states, expedited partner therapy for gonococcal infection treatment is allowed to facilitate partner management and prevent further infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs. Thus, parental consent is not required. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

E) CORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of addiction and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., STIs, contraception, pregnancy); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential from his parents (although minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, since Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is a reportable disease, the physician is required to report the case to a public health official. Ideally, all of the patient's sexual partners within the past 60 days should be informed (either by the patient or by the public health official, but not by the physician!), evaluated for gonococcal infection, and treated if positive. Alternatively, the physician could provide expedited partner therapy (EPT), especially if the likelihood of follow-up is low.

Intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone is used both for targeted and empirical therapy for gonococcal infection. If chlamydial coinfection is present or has not been ruled out, oral doxycycline is added. If EPT is required, a single dose of oral cefixime can be administered instead of ceftriaxone. If chlamydial infection is present or has not been excluded in the patient's partner, doxycycline (preferred) or azithromycin should be added.
questions.hint: In the United States, adolescents are able to provide consent for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for the evaluation of occasional epigastric pain, nausea, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and a history of recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. Ten years ago, the patient was diagnosed with brief psychotic disorder after the death of his wife. Since then, his mental status has been stable. He lives alone and takes care of all his activities of daily living. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. His current medication is metformin. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a pancreatic mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas that is classified as unresectable. A needle biopsy specimen of the mass confirms a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. When the doctor wants to enter the patient's room to reveal the diagnosis to the patient, he is approached by the son who says, “If it's cancer, please don't tell him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician?

choices.text: "I will respect your wish to withhold the diagnosis from your father."
"I can help you disclose the diagnosis to your father. He has a right to know."
"Can you tell me why you don't want your father to know about the diagnosis?"
"As his physician, I cannot withhold any information about your father's health from him."
"I propose a psychiatric consultation to assess your father's mental competence."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with decision-making capacity have the right to full disclosure and, therefore, the right to know their diagnosis based on the principle of autonomy. Because there is no evidence to suggest that this patient lacks decision-making capacity, the son does not have the right to make medical decisions for his father.

B) INCORRECT:

The physician has a duty to directly disclose a diagnosis to a patient. Transferring this responsibility to a relative of the patient is inappropriate and unprofessional. It can, however, be beneficial to include family members in the discussion to bridge any communication gaps or for emotional support, as long as the patient has consented to the physician disclosing health information to family members.

C) CORRECT:

Patient autonomy is one of the four core principles of medical ethics. When a patient's family or friends make a request for nondisclosure, it is critical to understand why the request has been made because this will inform physicians of how best to approach disclosure while respecting cultural differences or other concerns. Understanding the motivation behind such requests may also uncover explicit reasons not to tell the patient (e.g., grounds for invoking therapeutic privilege, patient preference to not know the diagnosis). Furthermore, it promotes rapport and a trusting relationship with the family. In most cases, cognitively intact patients should be informed of the diagnosis so that they can make appropriate medical decisions. Practical approaches to disclosing a sensitive diagnosis include understanding the patient's preference and incremental disclosure (SPIKES protocol).

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitively intact patients have the right to know their diagnosis. However, the son's request for nondisclosure raises concern for cultural or personal considerations that the physician might be unaware of. In addition, disregard for the son's request may hurt any established or potential physician-family relationship that could be beneficial moving forward. Other approaches should be considered before disclosing the diagnosis to the patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A psychiatric consultation is beneficial to patients with active psychiatric conditions that might undermine or interfere with their decision-making capacity. For patients with a psychiatric history, engaging their primary psychiatrist can help to ascertain their baseline capacity. Although this patient has a history of psychiatric illness, his mental status is currently stable and there is no other evidence to suggest that a psychiatric disorder is impairing his decision-making. A psychiatric consultation at this time would not be appropriate.
questions.hint: A patient with decision-making capacity has the right to full medical disclosure unless there is a good reason to withhold information.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with a rare type of bladder cancer comes to a urology cancer center for further diagnostics and treatment. Cystoscopy with biopsies discloses urachal adenocarcinoma in a locally advanced stage. The physician explains that there is currently no standard treatment for the patient's cancer. His only chance of curative treatment is to participate in a clinical trial using a novel operation technique to remove the tumor. After full disclosure of the experimental protocol, the potential hazards and benefits, and discussion of alternative treatment options, the patient consents to participate in the study. One year after the surgery has been successfully performed and during the second-to-last follow-up examination of the trial, the patient tells the physician that he does not want to participate in the study any longer. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "You can withdraw from your decision to participate in this study at any time."
"Can you tell me why you consented to participate if you don't want to complete the study after all?"
"I will have to consult with our research ethics committee before you can withdraw from the study."
”Withdrawal from the study after you gave your consent would be a breach of contract.”
"Please reconsider your decision as your participation in this study could help many other people with your condition."

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acknowledging this patient's right to withdraw from the clinical trial at any time is the most appropriate response in this case. According to regulations established by the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP) of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, all subjects enrolled in a study have the right to discontinue their participation at any given time, for any or no reason, without incurring a penalty or loss of benefit which they were entitled to for participating in the study. The investigator cannot obtain any further information without the subject's consent.

If the study is not subject to Food and Drug Administration (FDA) review and the subject requests that the data already collected be destroyed, the investigator may honor the subject's requests depending on the protocol set up by the institutional review board. For studies subject to FDA review, the investigator cannot destroy this information or exclude it from analysis. For interventional studies, data regarding adverse events might be important to protect the safety of other research subjects, and the OHRP, therefore, recommends that the investigator clarify with the subject whether they wish to withdraw completely from the trial or only from the primary interventional component. If the subject wishes to withdraw only from the primary interventional component, follow-up data collection can continue after reobtaining the subject's consent.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's change of mind and refusal of potentially life-saving treatment may warrant further inquiry from the physician; however, it should not intimidate or put any emotional pressure on the patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A patient is allowed to withdraw from a clinical study at any point and does not require an ethics committee approval to do so.

D) INCORRECT:

Withdrawing from a clinical study at any point is the patient's legal right, and it would not constitute a breach of any agreement.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a patient's withdrawal from a clinical trial may have an impact on further results of the study, it does not allow the physician to disregard their decision to quit.
questions.hint: This patient is competent and has made a decision about his participation in the clinical trial.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Request that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
Speak to the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
Report the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test to the state medical board
Disclose to the patient that a colleague forgot to follow up on the results of the initial HIV test
Do not inform the patient since the error did not cause harm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A medical error should be promptly disclosed to the patient, regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm. The clinician should explain the error and any consequences and allow time for further discussion and questions. Requesting that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test is inappropriate because it would unnecessarily delay patient notification.

B) CORRECT:

When a clinician suspects a medical error, they must speak privately and nonjudgmentally with the responsible colleague to determine whether an error occurred and why (e.g., misunderstanding or laboratory error). To help reduce the risk of future errors, the clinician should encourage their colleague to report the incident using standard protocol. Most medical errors are caused by failures in health care systems, and incident reporting can contribute to the identification and improvement of systemic issues. If there is no longer a patient-physician relationship with the colleague, the clinician must comply with HIPAA regulations by initially obtaining the patient’s permission to contact the physician.

Additionally, the clinician should inform the patient of the previous test result and discuss its implications, ensuring transparency and prioritizing care. In this scenario, the patient does not have HIV, and no further testing is needed.

C) INCORRECT:

The physician should report the colleague directly to the state medical board if the colleague is suspected of committing gross misconduct (e.g., billing fraud, bullying, sexual harassment). At this point, this action is inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

It is inappropriate to make assumptions about a colleague's actions. Without investigating, the physician cannot definitively know the reason for the error (e.g., lack of follow-up or laboratory error). A different action is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Clinicians must inform patients about a medical error regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm.
questions.hint: The failure to provide full disclosure in a timely manner constitutes a medical error. The right action in this scenario is grounded in the principles of professional respect and a systems-based approach toward medical error.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He reports severe pelvic pain and difficulty moving his left leg. He has not lost consciousness since the accident and does not have any other symptoms. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 116/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a shorter left lower extremity compared to the right one, pelvic instability on palpation, and an inguinal hematoma. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a FAST scan, imaging of the head and cervical spine, and retrograde urethrography are normal. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left iliac fracture with symphysis diastasis. The patient is admitted to the hospital and scheduled for surgery. His daughter, who is an orthopedic trauma surgeon at the same hospital, comes to see him before the procedure. The patient asks his daughter to perform the surgery because he considers his daughter to be an “excellent surgeon” and believes that she would “act in his best interests.” Despite counseling by the primary attending orthopedic surgeon and the patient's daughter, the patient insists that his daughter perform the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the patient's daughter?

choices.text: Perform the surgery as the primary attending surgeon
Offer to manage the postoperative care of the patient
Recommend a transfer of care to a different hospital
Seek permission from the primary attending surgeon to be the assistant surgeon in the procedure
Inform the patient that it is illegal to perform surgery on a family member

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The American Medical Association clearly advises against physicians treating or performing surgery on family members because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. Exceptions to this recommendation include medical emergencies in which no other qualified physician is present and treatment of minor conditions. However, in this scenario, another trained specialist is available.

B) INCORRECT:

The American Medical Association clearly advises against physicians treating or performing surgery on family members because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. In this scenario, the patient explicitly asks for his daughter to perform surgery on him. Offering to manage the patient's postoperative care does not address his preferences. In addition, managing the patient's postoperative care places the daughter in the position of serving as the primary decision-maker in the patient's care, raising the aforementioned ethical issues.

C) INCORRECT:

Transferring the patient to a different hospital would unnecessarily delay treatment and not pay respect to the patient's preferences.

D) CORRECT:

Although there is no federal law that prohibits physicians from treating or performing surgery on family members, the American Medical Association clearly advises against it because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. Exceptions to this recommendation include medical emergencies in which no other qualified physician is present and treatment of minor conditions. In this scenario, the patient explicitly asks for his daughter to perform surgery on him. By asking the primary attending surgeon if she may assist in the procedure, the daughter manages to balance this ethical principle (avoiding treatment of family members) with patient autonomy (honoring her father's preferences).

E) INCORRECT:

There is no federal law that prohibits physicians from treating or performing surgery on family members, but the American Medical Association clearly advises against it because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. Informing the patient that it is illegal to perform surgery on a family member is inaccurate and does not respect the patient's preferences.
questions.hint: This patient has an unstable pelvic fracture and requires urgent surgery but insists on a specific course of action. Physicians should generally avoid treating friends or family members. A course of action that balances this ethical principle with the patient's preferences is most appropriate.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He has schizophrenia and advanced metastatic lung cancer. At a visit 3 weeks ago, the patient reported severe weight loss and loss of appetite. The physician recommended palliative percutaneous gastrostomy and explained the procedure as well as its benefits and possible complications. At the time, the patient objected to the procedure, stating that he did not wish to undergo any surgical procedures or life-prolonging interventions, including resuscitation. He designated his brother as the medical power of attorney. Current medications include quetiapine, hydromorphone-acetaminophen, and prednisolone. The patient appears cachectic and ill. He is 176 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. He is alert and fully oriented. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 23/30. He has a flat affect. He denies auditory, visual, and tactile hallucinations. At the current visit, the patient appears to have changed his mind and wishes to undergo the procedure. His brother is present during the consultation and strongly disagrees with the patient's choice. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?

choices.text: "I know that you initially decided against the procedure. Are you sure that you want a gastrostomy?"
"This must have been a difficult decision for you. Would you allow me to perform a preoperative assessment if this is your final choice?"
"I see that you have changed your mind. Could you explain to me in your own words what you understand about gastrostomy?"
"Your brother seems to disagree with your choice. Could you talk to him first?"
"This must be a difficult decision to make. Would you like to talk to another physician?"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the first part of this statement acknowledges the patient's wish via active listening (in keeping with the PEARLS model), it is followed by a close-ended question (i.e., the patient may respond with only a "yes" or "no”), which does not help to assess his decision-making capacity.

B) INCORRECT:

This statement acknowledges the patient's feelings in an empathetic manner, in keeping with the PEARLS model. However, performing a preoperative examination is premature at this time because the patient's decision-making capacity has not yet been assessed.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's sudden change in the decision to undergo an invasive surgical procedure, in combination with mildly impaired cognition (Mini-Mental State Examination score of 23/30) and features of schizophrenia (e.g., flat affect), should prompt a reassessment of his decision-making capacity. The first part of this statement acknowledges the patient's wish via active listening, in keeping with the PEARLS model. The second part helps to assess his decision-making capacity, which includes evaluation of the patient's understanding of the situation and ability to use information to make a choice. Though this patient has articulated a choice, it is not yet clear if he is able to assimilate and process the potential outcomes of the proposed procedure, despite the physician's previous explanations. Standardized instruments, such as the MacArthur Competence Assessment Tool, are used to evaluate capacity and legal competence and involve a semi-structured interview with open-ended questions to explore the patient's reasoning.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has named his brother the medical power of attorney (POA), and it is reasonable for him to discuss his condition and preferences with his brother. The POA is tasked with making decisions for the patient if the patient lacks decision-making capacity. In this scenario, the patient's decision-making capacity has not yet been assessed.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement acknowledges the patient's feelings in an empathetic manner, in keeping with the PEARLS model. However, referring this patient to another physician is not medically indicated at this time, and the patient has not requested to speak with another physician.
questions.hint: This patient wants to undergo an invasive surgical procedure with potential complications. It is important to reassess his decision-making capacity, especially because of his risk factors for impaired cognition.

questions.text: A 5-day-old breast-fed male newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowish discoloration of his eyes and skin. He was born at term following a vaginal delivery at home. The mother states that, initially, the newborn fed well every 2–3 hours but developed poor feeding and irritability over the past 24 hours. The mother received no prenatal care during her pregnancy. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 35th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and widespread jaundice. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. His serum unconjugated bilirubin concentration is 31.5 mg/dL. The physician explains to the parents that the newborn must receive an exchange transfusion and phototherapy. The parents refuse to consent to the treatment and request immediate discharge, stating that they want to try "natural” treatment options such as ginger tea and sunbathing. Despite counseling about the consequences of not treating the child, the parents do not change their decision. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Seek a court order to override the parents' decision
Admit the patient and initiate appropriate treatment
Discharge the patient and notify child protective services
Discharge the patient after the parents sign an "against medical advice" form

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Seeking a court order to override parental refusal of treatment is appropriate for medical conditions that potentially threaten the child's life or limb but do not require immediate treatment (e.g., early-stage cancer). However, this newborn has a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention, and a court order would take some time to procure.

B) CORRECT:

Although parental consent is usually required before minors (children < 18 years of age in most US states) receive medical care, it does not apply in emergency situations in which there is a legal obligation to treat in order to save a child's life or limb. Since severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia has a very high risk of permanent brain damage and death, it is a life-threatening medical emergency and immediate therapy is necessary. If the medical condition threatens the child's life or limb and the effective treatment can be delayed for a short while (e.g., early-stage cancer), a court order should be obtained if parents refuse the treatment, assuming all other measures to convince the parents have failed. Parental refusal to consent to therapy is legally permitted when there is no risk of serious harm to the minor (e.g., for most vaccination refusals) or when the minor has a terminal condition that does not have any effective treatment (e.g., advanced metastatic cancer, certain high-grade brain tumors).

C) INCORRECT:

Physicians are obligated to immediately file a report with child protective services (CPS) in the case of suspected child neglect or abuse. Although withholding treatment for life-threatening conditions, as the parents are doing here, can be counted as neglect, notifying CPS would not be the most appropriate initial action by the physician.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharging a patient who is a minor against medical advice is appropriate if there is no risk of serious harm to the patient (e.g., most cases of vaccination refusal or refusal of palliative treatment in a terminally ill minor). However, this newborn's condition is life-threatening and urgent intervention is required.
questions.hint: This newborn's severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (> 30 mg/dL) puts him at increased risk of bilirubin encephalopathy (i.e., kernicterus), which leads to permanent neurological damage and potentially death.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician as a new patient and requests a whole-body CT scan for cancer screening because she can feel that “there is something in her body.” Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She has had several jobs over the past 10 years but is currently unemployed and has Medicaid insurance. There is no family history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient explains that she has seen several physicians in the past, but all of them refused to order the requested test for her. She says, “You seem wonderful, unlike my previous physicians. They were all incompetent. I even filed a lawsuit against one of them!” On exploring the patient's fear of cancer and the reasons for her inquiry, she reports that she saw an online direct-to-consumer advertisement about whole-body CT scans. The physician explains when whole-body CT scans are performed and why the test is not indicated in her case. The patient becomes agitated and insists that the physician order the test. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request?

choices.text: "I understand that you are concerned about having cancer. I can order the test if you are willing to sign an against-medical-advice form."
"A whole-body CT scan is associated with high levels of radiation exposure. I would instead recommend an MRI scan, which is a safer alternative."
"There is no indication that you might benefit from this test. I cannot in good conscience order the test for you at this time."
"Unfortunately, your health insurance plan will not cover this test. Would you be willing to pay for it yourself?"
"I am sorry that there is nothing I can do for you at this point. If you insist on having the test, I think it would be best to see another physician."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This response shows empathy and acknowledges the patient's concerns, which helps to build a trusting patient-physician relationship. However, regardless of whether the patient signs an against-medical-advice form, it is not appropriate for the physician to order a nonindicated, potentially harmful screening test.

B) INCORRECT:

This response relies on the principle of shared-decision making, according to which patients and physicians decide on the best diagnostic and/or treatment option together. Although an MRI is not associated with radiation exposure and therefore has fewer potential risks than a CT scan, neither a CT scan nor an MRI is indicated in this case.

C) CORRECT:

This response firmly yet politely rejects the patient's request. When evaluating a patient's demand for nonindicated care, physicians need to balance the core ethical principles. The ethical principle of patient autonomy, according to which a physician only assists in making decisions corresponding to the patient's personal values, is overruled in favor of beneficence and nonmaleficence in this directive counseling approach. Since there is no evidence that the possible benefits of whole-body CT scanning of asymptomatic individuals (e.g., to relieve the fear of cancer) outweigh the potential harm (e.g., radiation exposure, potential detection of ill-defined abnormalities requiring follow-up testing and interventions), the physician is acting in the patient's best interest (beneficence) and preventing harm (nonmaleficence). Moreover, denying nonindicated investigations and interventions also helps to ensure more equitable care. Finally, it is important for the physician to emphasize that the test is currently not indicated; it might be indicated in the future.

The patient's behavior in this scenario resembles splitting, a psychological defense mechanism characteristic of borderline personality disorder. Splitting involves separating experiences or people into all-good and all-bad, such as this patient's negative description of her past physicians. To minimize the effects of splitting, health care providers should collaborate toward common management goals, communicate regularly, and clarify their roles in patient care.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients may require a test or treatment not covered by their insurance, in which case they should be informed about the option of paying for the service out of pocket. However, regardless of whether it is covered by her insurance, it is not appropriate for the physician to order a nonindicated, potentially harmful screening test.

E) INCORRECT:

While physicians should always inform patients of their right to seek an additional medical opinion, it is not appropriate to threaten to end the patient-physician relationship because the patient insists on having a nonindicated test. Also, sending the patient to another physician will not solve the problem. Denying the request for a nonindicated screening test is the correct action, which is why the physician should refrain from apologizing. Finally, it is not true that the physician cannot do anything at this point, when the patient could be counseled on other aspects of health maintenance.
questions.hint: This patient is asking for a cancer screening test that is not scientifically validated and not covered by her medical insurance. The physician should use a directive counseling approach when responding to her request.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the office with his wife because of a 1-week history of left-sided scrotal swelling. He is seen by a female physician. He has no scrotal pain or penile discharge. He has no history of any trauma to the region. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is sexually active with his wife and uses condoms consistently. Prior to the examination, he asks his wife to step outside the room. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. During the genitourinary examination, the patient says, “That feels good! I wouldn't mind if you continued.” In addition to telling the patient that the comment is inappropriate, which of the following is the most appropriate subsequent action by the physician?

choices.text: Report the incident to law enforcement authorities
Transfer the care of the patient to a male physician
Call the patient's partner back into the room
Request the presence of a chaperone
Use humor to diffuse the situation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inappropriate comments from patients are not an indication for notifying law enforcement authorities. Situations in which a physician must provide law enforcement authorities with patient information include suspected cases of injury caused by a criminal act and the abuse of children, elderly people, or people with disabilities.

B) INCORRECT:

Transferring the care of the patient to a male physician does not address this patient's inappropriate behavior. While it may be reasonable for the original physician to terminate the patient-physician relationship and transfer the patient's care if he continues to behave inappropriately, a more appropriate initial step is to attempt to address the behavior itself.

C) INCORRECT:

As part of the patient-physician relationship, physicians should try to create a comfortable environment in order to build trust and provide optimal care for their patients. This patient has requested that his wife is not present during the examination, and his request should be respected in order to maintain trust.

D) CORRECT:

As part of the patient-physician relationship, physicians should try to create a comfortable environment in order to build trust and fulfill their duty to provide optimal care for their patients. Inappropriate patient behavior can make fulfilling this duty challenging and should be addressed directly. In this scenario, telling the patient that his comment is inappropriate in a polite and direct manner (so as to not undermine the therapeutic alliance) and requesting the presence of a medical chaperone (i.e., an authorized member of the care team, who can act as an impartial observer and witness) can help create an environment in which all parties feel comfortable and respected. Family members and other close contacts are not appropriate medical chaperones. Additional strategies to prevent inappropriate behavior include asking direct, close-ended questions and performing only medically necessary portions of the examination to minimize contact.

E) INCORRECT:

Physicians may choose to use humor in the clinical setting to cultivate the patient-physician relationship. However, using humor to diffuse the situation in this scenario would downplay the seriousness of the patient's inappropriate behavior.
questions.hint: Although health care professionals should address inappropriate patient behavior (e.g., discrimination, sexist remarks), it should not be at the expense of the primary professional obligation to the patient.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated in a rehabilitation facility, where he has been receiving physical therapy since undergoing total right knee replacement 18 months ago. The patient claims that he has been “feeling great for 6 months now” and does not understand why his primary care physician insists on referring him for more physical therapy sessions. The physician at the rehabilitation facility notices that the primary care physician who referred the patient happens to be the owner of the rehabilitation facility. The patient's referral notes list musculoskeletal symptoms that the patient denies having. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Record the incident in the Physician Quality Reporting System
Notify the rehabilitation facility's peer review body
Contact the state medical licensing board
Disclose the incident to all patients referred by the owner
Report the incident to the local Physician Health Program

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Physician Quality Reporting System (PQRS) is used to monitor quality metrics of physicians and provides continuous feedback to physicians with the aim of improving the quality and cost-effectiveness of health care. This system is not used to report physician misconduct.

B) INCORRECT:

If a health care provider (HCP) suspected of misconduct is within the purview of the health care organization, the HCP may first be reported to an oversight authority within the organization (e.g., department chair, chief medical officer, peer review body). In this scenario, the owner of the rehabilitation facility, who is outside the purview of any oversight authority at the rehabilitation facility, is suspected of misconduct; a different regulatory authority must be informed.

C) CORRECT:

A suspected violation of medical licensing provisions should always be reported to an appropriate authority. A health care provider (HCP) who witnesses such a violation but fails to report it can be held liable for concealment. Suspected incidents of misconduct or incompetence can be reported initially to an oversight authority within the organization (e.g., department chair, chief medical officer, peer review body) if the HCP under suspicion is within the oversight authority's purview. The incident should be reported to the state medical licensing board (SMLB) if the HCP under suspicion is outside the oversight authority's purview (as in this scenario), the incident continues despite initial reporting, or, for any reason, the incident cannot be reported to an oversight authority. Complaints to the SMLB can be filed by anyone (e.g., patients, HCPs, other SMLBs), and, in some states, anonymously. Following a complaint to the SMLB, the licensee against whom the complaint is made receives a formal notification and is asked to make a statement and provide information to clarify the situation. If required, the SMLB can initiate formal hearings and/or initiate disciplinary actions (board orders).

In the case of billing fraud, the appropriate investigatory authority of the insurance provider (e.g., CMS office in cases of Medicaid or Medicare fraud) should also be informed. If the alleged misconduct potentially violates any criminal statutes, law enforcement authorities should also be informed. When a violation of a medical licensing provision is suspected to be due to physician impairment, it is appropriate to first inform the local Physician Health Program (PHP), which is supervised by the SMLB and can make recommendations to the SMLB if required.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals who have been affected from self-referrals or billing fraud should be informed once the incident has been investigated and the misconduct has been confirmed. However, a physician who witnesses the suspected misconduct does not have the right to check the records of patients with whom the physician does not have a patient-physician relationship, since this would be a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). Instead, the physician should report the incident to an appropriate body with investigatory authority that can determine whether multiple instances of self-referrals or billing fraud occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

The Physician Health Program (PHP) is responsible for preventing, detecting, and managing physician impairment due to mental health or substance use disorders and conditions that limit the physician's motor skills or cognitive capacity. This physician is suspected of misconduct, not impairment. Therefore, an organization other than the PHP should be informed.
questions.hint: The owner of the rehabilitation facility is suspected of engaging in self-referral (Stark law violation) and billing fraud, both of which are examples of professional misconduct.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the hospital for evaluation 12 hours before a scheduled cholecystectomy. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with cholelithiasis after recurrent episodes of biliary colic. Current medications include oral contraceptives and multivitamins. The physician obtains informed consent only for the cholecystectomy and the patient is brought to the operating room. After induction and anesthesia, the surgeon removes the gallbladder but also finds a 3-cm, ill-defined subcapsular mass in the right lobe of the liver. Results of a frozen section from the lesion are consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma, which will require additional surgery. The patient has no durable medical power of attorney. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Proceed with additional surgery without obtaining consent
Decrease the patient's sedation until she is able to provide consent
Contact the patient's next of kin
Close the patient and obtain consent for a second operation
Schedule an emergency hospital ethics consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Performing an additional surgical procedure without the patient's prior consent is only appropriate in emergency situations in which there is an immediate threat to the patient's life or health. Although the findings consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma are serious, they do not pose an immediate threat to this patient's life.

B) INCORRECT:

Although decreasing the patient's sedation in order for her to provide consent for proceeding with surgery would avoid an additional surgery at a later point, it would also subject the patient to unnecessary pain and potential psychological trauma. Moreover, a patient regaining consciousness from sedation is unlikely to immediately have full decision-making capacity.

C) INCORRECT:

Obtaining consent from a surrogate decision-maker, such as the patient's next of kin, is appropriate for a patient without decision-making capacity who requires a nonemergency procedure (e.g., cancer surgery). This patient, however, does not lack decision-making capacity and will be capable of giving consent as soon as she regains consciousness.

D) CORRECT:

Informed consent is a fundamental legal concept that applies to all physicians in all fields of medicine. If an incidental finding during surgery does not require immediate action, performing an additional procedure without patient consent is unlawful. In this patient undergoing cholecystectomy, the surgeon incidentally discovers hepatocellular carcinoma that does not currently pose immediate life-threatening harm. Therefore, closing the patient, waking her up, and obtaining consent is the most appropriate next step. In situations in which there is a threat of immediate harm if the patient is not treated, the need for full informed consent is waived. If a patient lacks decision-making capacity (e.g., due to coma), consent for nonemergency procedures should be obtained from the patient's designated medical power of attorney or, if there is no such designated person, a next of kin.

E) INCORRECT:

Consulting the hospital ethics committee is appropriate for a patient without decision-making capacity who requires a nonemergency procedure (e.g., cancer surgery) and whose surrogate decision-maker is not available or is thought to be acting against the patient's preferences or best interest. This patient, however, does not lack decision-making capacity and will be capable of giving consent as soon as she regains consciousness.
questions.hint: This patient has not given preoperative consent for liver surgery. In such cases, it is important to evaluate the life-threatening potential of findings, which will determine further management.

questions.text: A surgeon who is on-call for the weekend is called in to perform an emergency appendectomy on a 19-year-old man who was diagnosed with perforated appendicitis and generalized peritonitis in the emergency department. The patient retained decision-making capacity at the time of diagnosis and a surgical resident obtained informed consent from the patient for the procedure. The on-call surgeon is 30 minutes late and the operating room staff is unable to reach her by telephone to confirm the instruments and materials she requires for the procedure. When she arrives, the scrub technician smells alcohol on the surgeon's breath and then confirms this suspicion with the nurse anesthetist present for the case. If the on-call surgeon performs the procedure in her current state, which of the following principles of patient care would most likely be violated?

choices.text: Beneficence
Justice
Autonomy
Nonmaleficence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In medical ethics, beneficence refers to acting in the best interest of the patient (“do good”). Surgical management of appendicitis in this patient is in his best interest. However, the surgeon's intoxicated state impairs the safety of the procedure and puts the patient at risk of harm due to a medical error. While it is the intention of the surgeon to do good, the principle to “do no harm” would be violated if she continued with the procedure in her impaired state.

B) INCORRECT:

In medical ethics, justice refers to treating patients fairly and equitably, i.e., treatment is determined by the patient's specific medical needs (in contrast to treating all patients the same way). This patient needs an emergency appendectomy and is scheduled for this procedure, so the principle of justice is upheld.

C) INCORRECT:

In medical ethics, autonomy refers to a patient or guardian's right to make decisions about whether or not to undergo treatment. This patient is legally emancipated, retained full decision-making capacities at the time of the diagnosis, and a surgical resident obtained informed consent for the procedure. The principle of patient autonomy is therefore respected.

D) CORRECT:

Nonmaleficence is the medical ethical principle of avoiding patient injury or suffering (i.e., “do no harm”). Most decisions in patient care require weighing the principle of nonmaleficence against the principle of beneficence (i.e., acting in the patient's best interest). In this scenario, the patient has an indication for an emergency appendectomy, and surgical management is in his best interest (principle of beneficence). However, the patient is at risk of serious harm due to physician impairment, and this risk cannot be outweighed by the benefits of having the procedure done by an impaired physician. The operating room staff needs to prevent the surgeon from performing the appendectomy and find a substitute surgeon.

In addition, the Physician Health Program (PHP) should be informed about the incident. The PHP will perform a thorough assessment of the physician and arrange appropriate management and support if an impairment is confirmed. Note that the PHP is not obliged to notify the state medical board if the physician accepts treatment of the impairing condition.
questions.hint: A physician who is impaired (e.g., an intoxicated surgeon) has a higher risk of committing a medical error that causes injury to the patient.

questions.text: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?

choices.text: Malpractice
Misconduct
Slip
Mistake
Lapse

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medical malpractice occurs when a healthcare provider violates professional standards through negligent conduct or acts of omission, resulting in patient harm. The elements of malpractice (i.e., the 4 Ds) are the duty to properly treat the patient, dereliction of that duty, damage to the patient, and direct cause of damage through medical negligence. Although Physician A neglected the duty to treat his patients, none have been directly damaged. Therefore, he did not commit malpractice and a different term describes his actions.

B) CORRECT:

Physician misconduct is any behavior that goes against the ethical principles of medical practice. In this scenario, physician A leaves the hospital and puts patients at risk through his absence, which violates the principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence. This behavior is never acceptable regardless of whether it results in harm to a patient or incurs legal consequences. Misconduct can also occur outside the established physician-patient relationship and does not always constitute malpractice (e.g., research malfeasance, fraudulent advertising). Other examples of misconduct include bullying, making inappropriate comments and/or sexually harassing colleagues or patients, billing fraud, and receiving gifts from patients or pharmaceutical industry representatives. Colleagues who suspect a physician of misconduct should report their concerns to the state medical board, and, if the misconduct implies any legal liability, to the appropriate legal authorities.

C) INCORRECT:

Slip is an unintentional active error in the performance of a task that is caused by a lack of mindful attention (e.g., accidentally pushing the bolus button instead of giving the medication in infusion). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

D) INCORRECT:

A mistake is a failed outcome resulting from an intentional action because of an error in execution and/or planning (e.g., making a misdiagnosis during an emergency and subsequently performing the wrong diagnostic test). Mistakes are more likely to occur while under time pressure, during multitasking and the execution of complex tasks, and when there is a lack of experience. Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

E) INCORRECT:

A lapse is an unintentional active error caused by a lack of mindful attention and a fault in memory (e.g., forgetting about a patient's penicillin allergy and prescribing amoxicillin). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.
questions.hint: Physician A's behavior violates the ethical principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for elective surgical repair of a right-sided inguinal hernia. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension and colorectal carcinoma, for which he underwent right-sided hemicolectomy 7 years ago. His medications are metoprolol and lisinopril. Physical examination shows a soft and reducible mass in the patient's right inguinal region and a well-healed midline scar. The patient is scheduled for an open hernioplasty on the next day. The attending surgeon who will perform the procedure expects no significant complications. A fourth-year medical student who is on rotation in the surgical ward asks if she may scrub in and participate as a second assistant in the procedure. She has sufficient experience in the operating room from previous clerkships. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the attending surgeon?

choices.text: Allow the student to observe the procedure only
Allow the student to participate under supervision
Introduce the student as a colleague and inform the patient about her participation in the procedure
Ask the student to inform the patient about her participation in the procedure
Disclose the student’s identity and training status to the patient and ask for consent

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Students are allowed to participate in patient care if certain steps to ensure patient autonomy are taken. Refusing the student's request to participate in surgery protects the patient's autonomy but neglects the surgeon's training responsibility. Therefore, the attending surgeon should take additional steps to inquire about the student's wish to participate in care.

B) INCORRECT:

The attending surgeon is responsible for supervising student participation in patient care, especially during surgery. However, the student is not allowed to participate without the prior agreement of the patient, who has the right to refuse student involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

The attending surgeon is responsible for informing the patient about the student's identity and desire to participate in care. However, using misleading terms, such as “colleague,” obscures the student's role and experience level and therefore contradicts the principles of beneficence and patient autonomy.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient has the right to choose whether a student is involved in their care (autonomy), and the attending surgeon is responsible for providing the patient with all of the necessary information to make a decision. Therefore, it is not appropriate to ask the student to inform the patient, and the attending surgeon should take additional steps to inquire about the student's wish to participate in care.

E) CORRECT:

Before surgery, a patient (or their surrogate) should be briefed about the risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and authorize the plan. A physician should balance their responsibility to train medical students with their obligation to provide optimal care (nonmaleficence) while upholding the rights of the patient (autonomy). If a student wishes to assist in surgery, the attending surgeon should inform the patient about the student's identity and level of training, and the patient must give informed consent for participation. As with any other decision, the patient has the right to refuse student involvement in their care at any time.
questions.hint: Student participation in patient care is an important method for developing critical competencies (e.g., empathy, clinical thinking, patient management).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician's office for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with asthma 5 years ago. He has responded poorly to treatment and requires frequent visits to the physician. He has been a patient at the physician's practice for several years and is, as usual, accompanied by his single mother. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother says, “Thank you for everything you have done for my son. Would you be interested in going on a lunch date with me next week while my son is away at summer camp?” The physician is not currently in a romantic relationship and is interested in getting to know the mother better. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "I will accept your invitation under the condition that we do not discuss your son's medical care during lunch."
"I will accept your invitation under the condition that the care of your son is transferred to another physician."
“I will accept your invitation since you are not a patient of mine.”
"I must decline your invitation because your son is still a minor."
"I cannot accept your invitation because it would compromise your son's medical care."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In order to protect patient confidentiality, a physician should not disclose patient information to their surrogate decision-maker (e.g., a parent in the case of an unemancipated minor) in public areas (e.g., in a restaurant). However, the decision of whether it is ethical for the physician to engage in a relationship with a third party who is close to the patient is not influenced by whether or not the patient is discussed outside the care setting.

B) INCORRECT:

A physician may choose to terminate a patient-physician relationship under specific circumstances (e.g., if the patient is abusive). Discontinuing an existing patient-physician relationship to pursue a relationship with an involved third party is patient abandonment and physician misconduct.

C) INCORRECT:

Whether it is ethical for a physician to engage in a romantic or sexual relationship with a third party who is close to a current patient is not determined by the fact that the third party (in this case, the patient's mother) is not directly under the physician's care.

D) INCORRECT:

Whether it is ethical for a physician to engage in a romantic or sexual relationship with a third party who is close to a current patient is not determined by the fact that the patient is a minor.

E) CORRECT:

Third parties often make decisions that affect the patient's health and welfare and are vulnerable to a physician's influence. Initiating a personal relationship with a third party who is close to the patient (e.g., parent, spouse, partner) and plays an integral role in the patient's medical decision-making process is therefore inappropriate as it can compromise treatment (as well as autonomy and patient privacy in patients with decision-making capacity and legal competence). Such relationships can limit the physician's objectivity, exploit the trust of the third party, and negatively affect the patient's well-being, which is why the invitation should be declined.

While romantic or sexual relationships between physicians and current patients are always unethical, physicians (excluding psychiatrists) may engage in romantic or sexual relationships with patients if more than 1–2 years have passed since termination of the patient-physician relationship. Psychiatrists are in a special position of influence over their patients and should never engage in such relationships with current or former patients.
questions.hint: Going on a date with the patient's mother may lead to a romantic or sexual relationship, which would likely affect the patient's clinical treatment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who works as an account manager in the hospital comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pain and swelling of the penis. Initially, the patient is reluctant to disclose the mechanism of injury but then admits that it occurred during penetrative sexual intercourse at a swinger party. He says that he heard a cracking sound, which was followed by intense pain and an immediate loss of erection. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows hematoma and curving of the penis. He is diagnosed with a penile fracture and undergoes uncomplicated surgical repair. After surgery, the patient asks the physician if they could change the diagnosis in his medical records because he is ashamed that his colleagues may read them. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Reject the patient's request
Request the patient to submit a formal application to the medical records department
Accept the patient's request and make a time-stamped note that the record was modified
Accept the patient's request, but inform him that the alteration will result in out-of-pocket expenses for the care provided
Reject the patient's request and report it to the hospital ethics committee

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medical records are legal documents; the information provided should be complete and accurate. Intentional falsification of medical records may constitute misconduct and lead to serious consequences for the physician, even if the medical care provided was appropriate. Therefore, the physician should reject the patient's request and reassure him that his records are treated confidentially.
